item.title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi
item.description: A rollicking pirate adventure AND an extensive bibliography for the historical accuracies! Be still my heart! This was brilliant. It would be easier to make a list of the things I didn’t like about it than all the things I loved.

item.title: The Curse of Chalion
item.description: It’s been easier lately for me to review the books I don’t like than the ones I do, because the ones I do, it’s just love, love, love.

item.title: Paladin of Souls
item.description: Magnificent. I didn’t think Bujold could top Cazaril as a character, and she does. Illvin and beloved Ista. Such a rich, full, scarred world she’s created.

item.title: The Hallowed Hunt
item.description: Not the heights of Ista or Cazaril, but going backwards in this timeline instead of forwards is a choice I admire.

item.title: Conversion
item.description: A 12th century missionary finds shelter in a blizzard with a gruff, kindhearted hermit. The conversion is his own, shedding the self-loathing shame for genuine tender romantic connection.

item.title: Decameron
item.description: Hey, remember way back when there was this pandemic happening? This was good reading during it.

item.title: Gwen & Art Are Not in Love
item.description: I think it wobbled a smiiiidge on the landing, a few things felt abrupt and/or undercooked, not to mention the jarring tonal shift into violence, but the ride to get there was super fun.

item.title: Kushiel’s Dart
item.description: My semi-decennial attempt to finish this book. I made it farther this time, with determination, but despite an attempt every three to five years, I still bounce off it like a rubber ball.

item.title: Lent
item.description: It seems like every year there’s a book that I want to beg people to read because I struggle to describe it, and it’s nothing like what they’d expect.

item.title: Machiavelli in Love
item.description: Ruggiero does it again: a great companion piece to months of Renaissance reading, including [[authors/niccolo machiavelli|Machiavelli]].

item.title: Orlando Furioso
item.description: A note on translation: I used Reynolds to compare, contrast, and fill in the gaps with the [[books/orlando furioso a new verse translation|Slavitt translation]].

item.title: Orlando Furioso: A New Verse Translation
item.description: Ariosto writing like AO3 was a thing in the sixteenth century. I love it. Fiendishly clever layers of satire; a story where anything goes.

item.title: The Autobiography of Benvenuto Cellini
item.description: Necromancy, assassinations, prison breaks, poisonings, stabbings (so many stabbings!I), pranks on Michelangelo… dude lived a life. Come for the adventure, stay for the fascinating glimpse into Renaissance life and art.

item.title: The Castle of Crossed Destinies
item.description: A lot of [[authors/ludovico ariosto|Ariosto]], a little of [[authors/giovanni boccaccio|Boccaccio]], a lot of Homer, Sophocles, and Shakespeare and a little of [[authors/dante alighieri|Dante]] too.

item.title: The Renaissance in Italy
item.description: One of the most accessible yet in-depth histories I’ve read. Lively and engaging. It’s been my tour guide through the past month of [[authors/dante alighieri|Dante]], [[authors/benvenuto cellini|Cellini]], [[authors/niccolo machiavelli|Machiavelli]], [[authors/ludovico ariosto|Ariosto]], et.

item.title: The Spirit Ring
item.description: Sometimes when things connect, they really connect. I picked this up because I was ready for another Bujold, and this is what the library had, and what is right there when I open it up?

item.title: Thornhedge
item.description: Aaaah the greenteeth! Toadling! A knight to the rescue that I don’t want to punch in the throat! But the GREENTEETH!
